revision.text:
[[File:Whiteboard animation video example.png|thumb|Whiteboard animation video example]] [[File:Whiteboard-Animation-Example.png|thumb|Whiteboard-Animation-Example]]
'''Whiteboard animation''' is the process of which an author physically draws and records an illustrated story using a [[whiteboard]]- or whiteboard like surface- and [[Marker pen|marker pens]]. The animations frequently are aided with narration by script. The authors commonly use [[stop motion]] animation to liven hand drawn illustrations, with [[YouTube]] used as a common platform. It is also used in television and internet advertisements to communicate to consumer's in a personal way. The earliest videos made using Whiteboard Animation were published in 2009 on [[YouTube]], used mostly for experimental purposes until developing into a story telling device, focusing majority on narratives, though it has many other uses in modern day.
== Description ==
"Whiteboard animation" refers to a specific type of presentation that uses the process of creating a series of draw pictures on a [[whiteboard]] that are recorded in sequence and then played back to create an [[animated]] presentation. The actual effect of whiteboard animation is time-lapse, or stop-motion. Actual sequential frame by frame animation is rarely used but has been incorporated. Other terms are "video scribing" and "animated doodling". These video animation styles are now seen in many variations, and have taken a turn into many other animation styles. With the introduction of [[software]] to create the whiteboard animations, the process has many different manifestations of varying quality. Those who use whiteboard animation are typically businesses and educators.
== Process == The whiteboard animation production procedure begins with creating a topic. Once the topic is chosen, script writing begins. After the content is created, it is time to create rough drafts of animations. These assist to set up the inventive bearing and timing for the movement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whiteboardanimation.com/process|title=Getting Started with Your Whiteboard Animation Production Process {{!}} Whiteboard Animation|last=Studio|first=Whiteboard Animation|website=www.whiteboardanimation.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> The rest of the process is as follows: # Compose the content # Record the voiceover # Make starting animations # Organize the animations # Make Guides # Record the video # Match up sound and video # Include music # Fare and Share<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://uxmastery.com/how-to-create-a-budget-whiteboard-animation/|title=How To Create A Budget Whiteboard Animation|date=2013-10-08|work=UX Mastery|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-US}}</ref> The steps listed above are not set in stone, they should be used as a guideline to create a whiteboard animation production.
== Applications ==
Whiteboard animation has been used in a few TV spots and on internet video sites such as [[YouTube]] and [[Vimeo]]. Early types were UPS Whiteboard Commercials. Many companies and firms of all sectors and sizes are incorporating this style into their modus operandi to teach company employees different company policies or demonstrate a new software or product to consumers.
For educational purposes, whiteboard animation videos have been used for learning online to teach languages, as chapter summaries for educational textbooks, and for the public communication of academic scholarship.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Thon|first1=Jonathan N.|last2=Kitterman|first2=Alice C.|last3=Italiano Jr.|first3=Joseph E.|title=Animating platelet production adds physiological context|journal=Trends in Molecular Medicine|date=2013|volume=19|issue=10|pages=583–585|doi=10.1016/j.molmed.2013.07.010|pmid=23953478|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1471491413001317|accessdate=4 April 2018|pmc=4418476}}</ref> A 2016 study of whiteboard animation found that, despite claims and high popularity, there is little to no compelling experimental evidence that they are more effective in learning, motivation, or persuasion than other forms of learning.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Türkay|first1=Selen|title=The effects of whiteboard animations on retention and subjective experiences when learning advanced physics topics|journal=Computers & Education|date=2016|volume=98|pages=102–114|doi=10.1016/j.compedu.2016.03.004|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0360131516300550|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref>
Starting in 2010, the [[Royal Society of Arts]] converted selected speeches and books from its public events program into whiteboard animations. The first 14 [[RSA Animate]] videos gained 46 million views in 2011, making the RSA's YouTube channel the no.1 nonprofit channel worldwide.<ref> Halliday, Josh (21 October 2011), [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/oct/21/internet-users-animated-rsa-films "Internet users get animated about RSA short film series"], ''The Guardian''.</ref>
